settings.liquid:
Electric Scooter Maintenance

A little regular care goes a long way. Use this checklist to keep your scooter safe, smooth and running for years.

Better braking & handling Longer tyre & battery life Fewer repairs & surprises
Quick Maintenance Checklist
Start here if you're new to e-scooters. Tap the sections below for full details.

Before Every Ride

Basic safety checks that take under a minute.

  • Check tyre pressure & visible damage.
  • Make sure wheels & handlebars are aligned.
  • Test brakes for quick, smooth engagement.
  • Confirm folding mechanism is fully locked.

Every 2–4 Weeks

Deeper checks for regular riders.

  • Give the scooter a proper clean.
  • Inspect brake pads, rotors & cables.
  • Top up lubrication on moving parts (not brakes).
  • Re-check all visible fasteners.

When Storing

Looking after your scooter off the road.

  • Store in a clean, dry, ventilated spot.
  • Avoid extreme heat or cold.
  • Charge battery fully before long-term storage.
Detailed Maintenance Guide

Proper tyre pressure improves speed, braking and handling, and helps prevent punctures.

What to do

  • Before each ride, check that pneumatic (air-filled) tyres are inflated to the manufacturer’s recommended pressure (typically around 50 PSI).
  • Use a tyre pressure gauge to measure accurately.
  • Use a pump to adjust the pressure as needed.

What to check

  • Make sure the handlebars and wheels are properly aligned and respond accurately to steering.
  • Check for any wobble or looseness in the stem or headset.
  • Remove debris or dirt from the wheels that could affect movement.

Before you ride

  • Test the brakes to ensure they engage promptly and smoothly.

Inspect the components

  • For disc brakes, check pads for wear, cracks or uneven surfaces – replace if needed.
  • Inspect brake cables or hoses for fraying, kinks or damage.
  • Confirm that the brake lever returns properly and doesn’t feel spongy or stuck.

Before each ride

  • Confirm that the folding mechanism is fully locked in the riding position.
  • Check locking pins, levers and safety catches for proper engagement.

Ongoing care

  • Clean the mechanism to remove dust, grit and debris.
  • Lightly lubricate moving parts occasionally to keep operation smooth (avoid excess lubricant).

Cleaning

  1. Power off and remove the battery if possible. Always turn the scooter completely off. If your model has a removable battery, take it out and clean it separately with a dry cloth.
  2. Avoid high pressure water or soaking. Don’t use hoses, pressure washers or submerge the scooter. This can push water into bearings, wiring and the battery compartment – even if it has an IP rating.
  3. Use a damp cloth. Wipe the frame, deck and handlebars with a soft, slightly damp cloth. For tougher dirt, use a bucket of water with mild soap, wring the cloth out well and then wipe.
  4. Target wheels and undercarriage carefully. Use a soft brush or old toothbrush to remove mud or grit from tyres, wheel hubs and suspension parts. If you rinse the wheels, pour a small amount of water directly onto the rubber only, avoiding axles and brakes.
  5. Clean brake rotors properly. Use disc brake cleaner or rubbing alcohol. Don’t use soap or oily cleaners on rotors – they reduce braking power.
  6. Dry thoroughly. Use a dry microfibre towel to remove moisture. Let the scooter sit in a dry, shaded area for at least an hour before charging or riding.
  7. Protect exposed connections. If you ride in wet conditions often, consider a light silicone grease on exposed electrical connectors and check rubber gaskets for wear.

Lubrication

  • Apply a PTFE-containing lubricant to appropriate moving parts such as folding joints, suspension components and headset bearings.
  • Avoid getting any lubricant on brake pads, rotors or braking surfaces.

Environment

  • Store your scooter in a clean, dry and well-ventilated area.
  • Avoid direct sunlight, heavy moisture and extreme temperatures.

Battery care

  • Charge the battery to full before longer-term storage.
  • Don’t leave the battery fully drained for long periods.

Regular checks (about every 2 weeks)

  • Give the scooter a general inspection for cleanliness and obvious wear.
  • Confirm all key components (tyres, brakes, folding mechanism, lights) are functioning properly.

Monthly tasks

  • Do a more thorough wash and dry of the scooter.
  • Check and adjust tyre pressures.
  • Reapply lubrication where needed (not on braking surfaces).

Periodic maintenance

  • Inspect cables, fasteners and any chains/belts for wear or looseness.
  • Tighten or replace components that show damage or excessive play.

For complex repairs or if you’re unsure about any maintenance task, it’s best to consult a professional technician or contact our team. Proper maintenance keeps you safe, improves performance and extends the life of your scooter.

settings.content: Maintaining your electric scooter is essential for ensuring safety and prolonging its lifespan. Here's a comprehensive checklist to guide beginners through proper e-scooter maintenance

1. Tyre Pressure

  • Check Regularly: Before each ride, ensure your pneumatic (air-filled) tyres are inflated to the manufacturer's recommended pressure, typically around 50 PSI. Proper inflation enhances speed, braking, and handling.
  • Tools Needed: Use a tyre pressure gauge to measure and an air pump to adjust the pressure as necessary.

2. Wheels and Handlebars

  • Inspect Alignment: Ensure the handlebars and wheels are properly aligned and respond accurately to steering inputs.
  • Remove Obstructions: Clear any debris or dirt from the wheels that might impede movement.

3. Brakes

  • Test Responsiveness: Before riding, test the brakes to ensure they engage promptly and effectively.
  • Inspect Components: For disc brakes, examine brake pads for wear, such as cracks or uneven surfaces, and replace them if necessary. Check brake cables for fraying or damage and ensure the brake lever functions correctly.

4. Folding Mechanism

  • Secure Locking: Before each ride, confirm that the folding mechanism is securely locked to prevent accidental folding during use.
  • Regular Maintenance: Clean the mechanism to remove debris and lubricate it occasionally to ensure smooth operation.

5. Cleaning and Lubrication

  • Cleaning:

1. Power off and remove the battery if possible

Always turn the scooter completely off.

If your model has a removable battery, take it out and clean it separately with a dry cloth.

2. Avoid high pressure water or full soaking

No hoses, pressure washers or dunking as that can push water into bearings, wiring and the battery compartment.

Even if it has an IP rating that does not mean it can handle direct high pressure spray.

3. Use a damp cloth

Wipe the frame, deck and handlebars with a soft cloth that is slightly damp.

For tougher dirt use a bucket of water with mild soap and dip the cloth then wring it out well before wiping.

4. Target the wheels and undercarriage carefully

Use a soft brush or old toothbrush to remove mud or grit from tyres, wheel hubs and suspension.

If you must rinse the wheels pour a small amount of water directly onto the rubber only avoiding axles and brakes.

5. Clean the brake rotors the right way

Use a proper disc brake cleaner or rubbing alcohol and never soap or oily cleaners as they reduce braking power.

6. Dry thoroughly

Use a dry microfiber towel to remove any moisture.

Let the scooter sit in a dry shaded area for at least an hour before charging or riding.

7. Protect exposed connections

If you ride in wet conditions often consider adding silicone grease to exposed electrical connectors and checking rubber gaskets for wear.

  • Lubrication: Apply a PTFE-containing lubricant to moving parts such as wheels, folding mechanisms, shock absorbers, and headset bearings. Be cautious to keep lubricant away from braking components.

6. Storage

  • Environment: Store your scooter in a clean, dry, and well-ventilated area, away from extreme temperatures and moisture.
  • Battery Care: Charge the battery to its full capacity before storing to maintain performance and longevity.

7. Maintenance Schedule

  • Regular Checks: Perform a thorough inspection every two weeks, focusing on cleanliness and functionality of all components.
  • Monthly Tasks: Conduct deeper maintenance monthly, including washing, lubrication, and tyre pressure adjustments.
  • Periodic Maintenance: Regularly inspect cables, fasteners, and chains for signs of wear or looseness, and address any issues promptly.

For complex repairs or if you're uncertain about any maintenance tasks, it's advisable to consult a professional technician. Proper maintenance not only ensures safety but also enhances the performance and extends the life of your electric scooter.
